Fairchildite.Environment: Dimorph with butschliite. The samples are fused wood-ash clinkers that occurs in partly burned fir and hemlock trees in many national parks and forest in the western United States.
Fairchildite.Name Origin: Named after John Gifford Fairchild (1882-1965), analytical chemist at the U. S. Geological Survey.
Fairchildite.Images:
Fairchildite
Comments: PPL thin-section image of fused wood-ash stone, showing slightly altered lath-shaped cross-sections of fairchildite in a fine groundmass containing buetschliite and calcite. Inset image shows sample.
Location: Kaniksu National Forest, Idaho. (AmMin, v32:607). Scale: Thin Section 30 X.
© American Mineralogist

Faizievite.Environment: Found in a quartz-pectolite boulder in moraine. Related to beryl-group and milarite-group minerals. Faizievite structure can be considered as alternating baratovite and berezanskite blocks alternating along [001].
Faizievite.Locality: Dar-i-Pioz glacier, Alai mountain range, northern Tajikistan. Link to MinDat.org Location Data.
Faizievite.Name Origin: Named for Faiziev Abdulkhak Radzhabovitrh (b 1938), professor of the Academy of Sciences of the Republic of Tadjikistan, Dushanbe, Tadjikistan.
Faizievite.Images:
Faizievite
Comments: Pale brownish yellow massive faizievite associated with quartz.
Location: Dara-i-Pioz Glacier, Alayskiy (Alai) Range, Tien Shan Mts, Districts of the Republican Subordination, Tajikistan. Scale: See Image.
© Rruff Database

Axinite-(Fe).Color: Brown, Purplish blue, Gray, Greenish yellow.
Axinite-(Fe).Fracture: Brittle - Conchoidal - Very brittle fracture producing small, conchoidal fragments.
Axinite-(Fe).Habit: Massive - Granular - Common texture observed in granite and other igneous rock.
Axinite-(Fe).Gladstone-Dale:
CI meas= -0.007 (Superior) - where the CI = (1-KPDmeas/KC)
CI calc= 0.002 (Superior) - where the CI = (1-KPDcalc/KC)
KPDcalc= 0.2079,KPDmeas= 0.2098,KC= 0.2082
Ncalc = 1.68 - 1.69
Axinite-(Fe).Pleochroism (x): colorless, yellow, light brown, yellow brown, or pale green.
Axinite-(Fe).Pleochroism (y): colorless, deep yellow, deep blue, pale violet, or violet.
Axinite-(Fe).Pleochroism (z): colorless, pale green, olive yellow, brown, or dark violet.
Axinite-(Fe).Electron Density:
Bulk Density (Electron Density)=3.27 gm/cc
note: Specific Gravity of Axinite-(Fe) =3.31 gm/cc.
Axinite-(Fe).Photoelectric:
PEAxinite-(Fe) = 5.68 barns/electron
U=PEAxinite-(Fe) x rElectron Density= 18.59 barns/cc.
Axinite-(Fe).Radioactivity:
GRapi = 0 (Gamma Ray American Petroleum Institute Units)
Axinite-(Fe) is Not Radioactive
Axinite-(Fe).Dana Class: 56.02.02.01 (56)Sorosilicate Si2O7 Groups and O, OH, F. and H2O
Axinite-(Fe).References: NAME( Duda&Rejl90) PHYS. PROP.(Larousse des Mineraux,1981) OPTIC PROP.(Heinrich65)

Ferronordite-(Ce).Environment: In areas of ultra-alkaline mineralization in small cavities in pegmatoid sodalite syenites. In ussingite veinlets.
Ferronordite-(Ce).Locality: Chinlusuia River, Lovozero Alkaline massif, Kola Peninsula, Russia. Link to MinDat.org Location Data.
Ferronordite-(Ce).Name Origin: Named as the Fe++ dominant analogue of nordite-(Ce). Nordite series is named after the word for north because of its northern origin in the Lovozero Massif.
Ferronordite-(Ce).Images:
Ferronordite-(Ce)   Ferronordite-(La)
Comments: Large complex rosette of ferronordite-(La) in center and ferronordite-(Ce) on terminations of platy crystals. Earthy yellowish rhabdophane is Ce dominant.
Location: Bolshoi Punkaruaiv Mt, Lovozero Massif, Kola Peninsula, Murmanskaja Oblast', Northern Region, Russia. Scale: FOV is 12x10 mm.
© Pavel M. Kartashov

Ferrowyllieite.Environment: Primary phosphate in zoned granite pegmatites. Forms a series with wyllieite and with rosemaryite.
Ferrowyllieite.Locality: Victory mine, 4 km northeast of Custer, Custer County, South Dakota, USA. Link to MinDat.org Location Data.
Ferrowyllieite.Name Origin: Dominant ferrous iron and relationship to wyllieite.
Ferrowyllieite.Images:
Ferrowyllieite
Comments: Deep greenish black massive ferrowyllieite with brown to white quartz.
Location: Victory Mine, near Custer, Custer County, South Dakota, USA. Scale: See Photo.
© Jeff Weissman / Photographic Guide to Mineral Species

Ferrowyllieite.Color: Bluish green, Greenish black, Gray green, Dark blue green.
Ferrowyllieite.Fracture: Brittle - Generally displayed by glasses and most non-metallic minerals.
Ferrowyllieite.Habit: Selvage - As a reaction rim, surrounding the host mineral.
Ferrowyllieite.Gladstone-Dale:

U=PEFerrowyllieite x rElectron Density= 32.61 barns/cc.
Ferrowyllieite.Radioactivity:
GRapi = 0 (Gamma Ray American Petroleum Institute Units)

Quartz.Fracture: Conchoidal - Fractures developed in brittle materials characterized by smoothly curving surfaces, (e.g. quartz).
Quartz.Habit: Druse - Crystal growth in a cavity which results in numerous crystal tipped surfaces.
Quartz.Luminescence: Fluorescent and Triboluminescent, Short UV=yellow-orange, Long UV=yellow-orange.
Quartz.Gladstone-Dale:
CI meas= -0.005 (Superior) - where the CI = (1-KPDmeas/KC)
CI calc= 0.005 (Superior) - where the CI = (1-KPDcalc/KC)
KPDcalc= 0.207,KPDmeas= 0.209,KC= 0.208
Ncalc = 1.54 - 1.55
Quartz.Electron Density:
Bulk Density (Electron Density)=2.65 gm/cc
note: Specific Gravity of Quartz =2.65 gm/cc.
Quartz.Photoelectric:
PEQuartz = 1.80 barns/electron
U=PEQuartz x rElectron Density= 4.76 barns/cc.
Quartz.Radioactivity:
GRapi = 0 (Gamma Ray American Petroleum Institute Units)
Quartz is Not Radioactive
Quartz.Strunz Class: 04.DA.05 04 - OXIDES (Hydroxides, V[5,6] vanadates, arsenites, antimonites, bismuthites, sulfites, selenites, tellurites, iodate

Franklinphilite.Environment: Metamorphosed, weathered zinc deposit. The manganese analog of stipnomelane.
Franklinphilite.Locality: Franklin mine, Sussex County, New Jersey. Link to MinDat.org Location Data.
Franklinphilite.Name Origin: Named after its locality and from the Greek philos = 'friend.' The 'friends of Franklin' are those scientific investigators who helped study the unique mineralogy and geology of th is deposit.
Franklinphilite.Images:
Franklinphilite

Location: Franklin mine, Sussex County, New Jersey.. Scale: Fragment Size 2.5 mm.

Franklinphilite.Fracture: Brittle - Generally displayed by glasses and most non-metallic minerals.
Franklinphilite.Habit: Radial - Crystals radiate from a center without producing stellar forms (e.g. stibnite)

CI calc= 0.02 (Excellent) - where the CI = (1-KPDcalc/KC)

Ncalc = 1.57 - 1.61
Franklinphilite.Electron Density:

note: Specific Gravity of Franklinphilite =2.65 gm/cc.
Franklinphilite.Photoelectric:

U=PEFranklinphilite x relectron= 24.61 barns/cc.
Franklinphilite.Radioactivity:

Meridianiite

Lechatelierite.Environment: Naturally occurring fused quartz as inclusions in igneous rock, lightning strikes in sandy soils, and meteor impacts.
Lechatelierite.Locality: Meteor Crater, Coconino County, Arizona, USA and other World wide occurrences. Link to MinDat.org Location Data.
Lechatelierite.Name Origin: Named for Henry Louis Le Chatelier (1850-1936), French-Italian chemist.
Lechatelierite.Images:
Lechatelierite   Trinitite
Comments: Fused silica sand (trinitite) generated by the first nuclear (fission) bomb. Although man-made and not a valid mineral, the specimen has historic value.
Location: Trinity Flats, White Sands, New Mexico. It came into existance at 5:29 a.m., July 16, 1945. Scale: Specimen size 4.1 cm.
© Paul M. Schumacher
Lechatelierite.Fracture: Conchoidal - Fractures developed in brittle materials characterized by smoothly curving surfaces, (e.g. quartz).
Lechatelierite.Habit: Porcelainous - Fine-grained, translucent massive material like broken china

Gadolinite-(Ce).Environment: In syenite pegmatite veins along a contact between basalt and monzonite.
Gadolinite-(Ce).Locality: From a dump at Buer, nine km southeast of Skien, Bjorkendalen region, and in the Bakken quarry, Tvedalen, Norway. Link to MinDat.org Location Data.
Gadolinite-(Ce).Name Origin: Named for its cerium content and the relationship to gadolinite-(Y).
Gadolinite-(Ce).Images:
Gadolinite-(Ce)
Comments: Sharp, well crystallized single crystal of brown gadolinite.
Location: Buer, Bjørkedalen, Porsgrunn, Telemark, Norway. Scale: 18x14x8 mm.
© John Betts - Fine Minerals
Gadolinite-(Ce).Crystal System: Monoclinic - PrismaticH-M Symbol (2/m) Space Group: P 21/c
Gadolinite-(Ce).Fracture: Brittle - Conchoidal - Very brittle fracture producing small, conchoidal fragments.
Gadolinite-(Ce).Habit: Metamict - Mineral originally crystalline, now amorphous due to radiation damage.

CI calc= 0.122 (Poor) - where the CI = (1-KPDcalc/KC)

Ncalc = 1.72 - 1.89

Concentration of Gadolinite-(Ce) per GRapi unit = 22.64 (PPM)
